doc.repnme: Good for business : women better customers of urban water supply services
doc.abstracts: This note briefly documents and experiment designed to show increasing attention to women could improve the success of the project. For over 20 years, the World Bank has been providing loans to support public water supply enterprises in Indonesia, originally through specific water supply projects and later through components of integrated urban development projects. The loans have been used to facilitate the provision of clean water to rapidly growing urban populations. During preparation of the projects, projections of the expected demand for household connections were made, to determine long-term financial viability of the water supply enterprises. However, the number of new connections actually made each year is consistently forecasted number. Without the income from new connections, and with reduced regular income from monthly fees, the water enterprises are no longer financially viable and need to be subsidized. In other cases, people are simply not choosing to apply for household connections. One reason is the perceived high cost of connections and the poor quality of service provided. To address these problems, investments through loans have aimed to improve the quantity, quality and delivery of clean water.
